text: If you get infected with Covid, the virus makes billions of copies and spreads all over your body. When you get vaccinated, the vaccine teaches your immune system how to recognize and kill the virus quickly, then disappears.
Preparedness works. The next pandemic threat is inevitable, but the next pandemic isn’t. https://t.co/Hsbc4aFW9K

As horrific as Covid is now, a future pandemic could be even worse. It's inevitable that there will be future disease threats, but it's not inevitable that they will become pandemics. We can stop them. https://t.co/2wtmyJaa6L https://t.co/mKeEnohzVV
On average, we identify one new deadly organism every year. When the next global health threat emerges, we must be prepared for it so we don’t repeat the story of Covid.

Covid started as single and potentially containable outbreak before spreading rapidly across the globe. If we invest in global preparedness and learn from recent outbreaks, we can prevent the next, inevitable threat from becoming a pandemic. https://t.co/bOzMusVhID
The virus that causes Covid is learning and adapting to humanity. If humanity doesn't learn and adapt, the virus will keep spreading, and killing.

Covid won’t be the last pandemic in our lifetime. This is our now-or-never moment to invest in public health and ensure the world is never again so underprepared for an infectious disease threat. https://t.co/2wtmyJaa6L https://t.co/4j6TUiD0hB
How can we prevent the next pandemic? By making sure every country in the world is able to identify, investigate, and respond to new health threats quickly.
The Covid pandemic didn't have to be nearly this bad. If the world had been prepared to contain and respond to the virus, millions of lives could have been saved. https://t.co/JSgxwImJVW

It's possible to stop the next infectious disease threat before it becomes a pandemic. Stay tuned for the launch of a first-of-its-kind report from @ResolveTSL tomorrow.
After you get vaccinated, protection from Covid isn't immediate or complete. It takes time for your immune system to build defenses against the virus. https://t.co/N1lDBSj7by

In the US, we'll be in a much better place by the fall. But around the world, the pandemic is nowhere close to over—in fact, it's getting worse. Masks. Distancing. Protection of health care and essential functions. And scaling up global vaccine production all essential.

I get ANGRY seeing this. Every building, every block, every community: Engaging, listening, planning. The next mile of Covid vaccination will require micro planning and meticulous implementation. NYC can do better when public health leads the way.

People with heart disease, lung disease, diabetes, and obesity are more likely to get very sick from Covid. If you have any of these conditions, it's especially important for you to get vaccinated.
When we vaccinate in communities hardest hit by Covid, we prevent more infections and save more lives.

Scaling up vaccine manufacturing is essential. Technology transfer of mRNA vaccines, which were created with taxpayer money, is particularly urgent. The World Needs Many More Coronavirus Vaccines https://t.co/OvEw88d6Tl

Covid vaccines are the results of decades of research, and the clinical trials included more than 100,000 people—more than many other clinical trials. No corners were cut in the development of these vaccines, just red tape.

Epic epi curves. And these data, and the world, could get a lot worse in the coming weeks and months. Globally, while the US makes progress, the Covid pandemic is a gathering storm, already hitting hard in many places, with many more at risk. https://t.co/sckL7M07Jo

Side effects after vaccination are a normal sign that your body is building protection against Covid. You may experience more intense side effects after your second shot, but they'll go away in a day or two – much faster than many people recover from Covid.

When you're fully vaccinated, the chances you'll get Covid are slim. When everyone around you is fully vaccinated too, the chances will be near zero. The more of us are vaccinated, the safer we all are.
